dataset.title: Development of Illumina oligos for fungal ITS sequencing

address.deliveryPoint: Department of Biology; MSC03 2020; 1 University of New Mexico

abstract.para: New PCR primers were designed with the following objectives: 1) targetting the ITS2 region to minimize bias due to introns at the 3' end of the SSU, 2) have the broadest possible coverage of Fungi, 3) minimize amplification of plant, protist and other Eukaryote sequences, 4) compatibility with Illumina sequencing adaptors and GOLAY barcodes. Primer regions were selected by eye from sequence alignments then further analyzed using PrimerProspector. At present, several mock communities and hundreds of soil DNA extracts have been successfully sequenced on the Illumina MiSeq platform using the oligos that were developed.

section.title: Experimental Design
section.para: The coverage and specificity of the new primers were compared with previously published fungal ITS primers using PrimerProspector. Mock communities were constructed from an array of 10 fungal species representing Chytridiomycota, Zygomycota, Ascomycota and Basidiomycota. Two communities were created with taxon relative abundances varying over 100 fold. Sequencing of several well-characterized soil DNAs from BNZ LTER was carried out in order to compare clone library Sanger sequencing with Illumina amplicon sequencing.

section.title: Methods
section.para: LAB: Oligos were designed as described in the Summary above. Bench testing was carried out by amplifying 2 replicates for each of two randomly chosen barcodes for each sample (mock community or soil DNA).PCRs were carried out using Amersham Ready-to-Go beads with 27 cycles of 94C denaturation, 55C annealing and 72C extension. PCRs from a single sample were pooled, quantified using PicoGreen and normalized. Up to 20 samples were pooled in a single library. Libraries were sequenced in 250bp paired end mode on a MiSeq machine at the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard.
